entry.title: Learning Circle Experience: Change Management in SAP-Projekten – Retrospektive und Erkenntnisse
entry.content:
Nach zwölf Wochen Peer-Learning zu Organizational Change Management (OCM) in SAP-Projekten trafen sich die Teilnehmenden am 16. Dezember 2025 zur finalen Retrospektive. Das Format basiert auf selbstorganisierten Lernzirkeln, die einen strukturierten Leitfaden (LernOS Leitfaden Change Management) als Grundlage nutzten und lebt vor allem vom Austausch der Teilnehmenden.

Check-In: Woher kommt ihr?

Die Teilnehmenden begrüßten sich und teilten ihre Standorte mit, darunter Mannheim, Bern, Karlsruhe, Mainz, Hamburg, Eckernförde, Oy-Mittelberg, Furtwangen, Kreuzlingen, Norderstedt und Rotenberg. Wir vom Orga-Team waren auf Einladung von Simon Dückert in Nürnberg in der Cogneon Akademie.

Inhaltliche und methodische Lern-Erfahrungen – Reflektion der Befragung

Im Vorfeld haben 30 Teilnehmende eine Umfrage beantwortet, die ich hier kurz zusammen fasse.

Die meisten Teilnehmenden der Retrospektive und der Umfrage haben die Leitfäden und Lerngruppen bis zum Ende durchgeführt. Aus dem Bauch heraus würde ich sagen, daß ca. die Hälfte der initial Angemeldeten und somit so ca. 100 -120 Personen in Lernzirkeln gelernt haben.

Was waren die Erfahrungen in den Lernzirkeln?

Wertvoller Austausch und Input

Die Teilnehmenden bewerteten den Peer-Austausch als zentralen Mehrwert. Viele Best Practices wurden geteilt, der Erfahrungsaustausch erwies sich als wertvoll. Die Diversität der Perspektiven und unterschiedliche Standpunkte zu Projekten wurden als sehr bereichernd empfunden.

Wir sehen das oft in Lernzirkeln: Der Leitfaden gibt die Struktur und etwas Input - das eigentliche Lernen erfolgt durch die Erfahrung & Reflektion der Gruppenteilnehmenden.

Positive Gruppendynamik

Die gemischten Vorkenntnisse der Gruppenmitglieder erwiesen sich als Stärke. Teilnehmende mit unterschiedlichem Change-Management-Wissensstand trafen sich wöchentlich. Die verschiedenen Herausforderungen und Themen, mit denen andere konfrontiert waren, boten interessante Einblicke. Der Mix an Know-how und Erfahrung machte die Treffen kurzweilig und spannend.

Positive Grundstimmung

Das Feedback war überwiegend positiv – die Teilnehmenden beschrieben die Erfahrung als bereichernd, inspirierend und herausfordernd, insbesondere wenn es darum ging, die Lernzeit mit der Arbeit zu vereinbaren. Die Initiative wurde als absolut positiv bewertet. Einige würden das Format "immer wieder gerne" nutzen.

Lernformat und Organisation

Die wöchentlichen Austauschtreffen funktionierten gut. Das Konzept des Lernens in Lerngruppen erwies sich als hilfreich. Der Gruppendruck half, das Ziel nicht aus den Augen zu verlieren. Die Organisation durch SAP wurde als gut strukturiert wahrgenommen.

Content und Methodik

Der angebotene Leitfaden erwies sich als sinnvoll. Die Kombination aus Selbststudium, Aufgaben verknüpft mit Projekterfahrung und Peer-Austausch funktionierte bei überschaubarem Zeitaufwand.

Fachliche Change-Management-Erkenntnisse

Die Teilnehmenden gewannen unterschiedliche inhaltliche Einsichten – anbei ein Auswahl:

  • Verschiedene grundsätzliche Change-Ansätze kamen zur Anwendung
  • Change Management gelingt am besten, wenn Menschen frühzeitig einbezogen, transparent informiert, empathisch begleitet und strukturiert durch den Veränderungsprozess geführt werden
  • Das Commitment des Managements muss vorhanden sein und auf Ernsthaftigkeit geprüft werden
  • Die Stakeholder-Analyse ist ein wichtiges Drehkreuz, weil damit die Beteiligten entsprechend eingebunden werden
  • Offene Kommunikation und aktives Zuhören sind zentral, um Veränderungen gemeinsam zu verstehen und erfolgreich umzusetzen
  • Bedeutung des Change Managements für organisationale Änderungen wurde vertieft, neue Aspekte kennengelernt

Herausforderungen beim Lernen in Lernzirkeln

Zeitliche Herausforderungen

Der Alltag mit seinen Herausforderungen kam oft in die Quere. Es erwies sich als schwierig, in einer Gruppe zu lernen, wenn viele andere Prioritäten dazwischenkommen. Die Teilnehmenden reflektierten: "Besser kurz als gar nicht" und "Zeit, die mit Lernen verbracht wird, ist gut investierte Zeit".

Abhängigkeit vom Engagement

Das Format funktioniert nur mit zuverlässigen, engagierten Teilnehmenden. Fehlendes Commitment anderer wurde als Problem genannt. Es braucht Wissensträger in der Gruppe.

Kritische Stimmen

Einzelne Teilnehmende fanden das Format nicht bereichernd. Für manche war und ist es wohl nicht das richtige Format. Auch fanden 2 Teilnehmenden die Inhalte oberflächlich – wobei der Leitfaden eigentlich für Beginner und Grundlagen gedacht ist.

Feedback aus einigen Lerngruppen

Innovative Praxis: KI-gestützte Change-Workshops und KI Begleitung

Simon Dückert lernte mit einem KI-Buddy alleine, da er für eine Lerngruppe keine Zeit hatte. Er berichtete von einem experimentellen Ansatz, bei dem er KI-Tools für Change-Management-Workshops und zur Konzeptgestaltung einsetzt. Die Methode kombiniert Change-Management-Literatur sowie den Leitfaden zusammen mit kundenspezifischen Dokumenten und nutzt Claude sowie Open WebUI. Das System generiert vollständige Konzeptdokumente inklusive Fahrplänen für zwölf Monate, Kommunikationsplänen mit Gantt-Diagrammen und personalisierten Lernpfaden.

Die Visualisierung erfolgt über das Mermaid-Format für Mindmaps und Gantt-Diagramme. Der entscheidende Vorteil: Am Ende des Workshops liegt ein konkretes Arbeitsdokument vor, nicht erst nach einer Woche Nachbereitung. Somit kann er sehr schnell und effizient Change-Management Konzepte erstellen. Geplant sind Chatbots, die den erweiterten Change-Kontext kennen und personalisierte Inhalte bereitstellen können.

Es gibt übrigens einen lernOS KI Leitfaden: https://ai.lernos.org. Er ist derzeit jedoch nicht voll up-to-date – Themen wie Reasoning Modelle, Agenten fehlen noch.

Erfahrungen aus der Gruppe "Changemakers"

Adelheid, die auch in Nürnberg zu Gast war, berichtete von ihrer Gruppe mit Ann-Kristin Bürke, Laura Schladitz, Tanita Bahr und Stefan Vossen. Die Dynamik basierte auf gegenseitiger Unterstützung: Laura stellte beispielsweise ein Hochschulangebot vor, bei dem Change-Prozesse vor Projektstart simuliert werden. Stefan Vossen teilte Praxisbeispiele zu SAP Enable Now, während Tanita Bahr bzgl. einem Bosch-Rollout ihre aktuellen Herausforderungen einbrachte und direktes Feedback erhielt.

Der Austausch funktionierte als wechselseitiges Lernen – jeder brachte seine Expertise ein, niemand war nur Lehrender oder nur Lernender. Der Leitfaden diente als Struktur, die eigentliche Lernerfahrung entstand durch den Dialog.

Erfahrungen aus der Gruppe "Freitags-Holzhacker"

Diese Gruppe traf sich regelmäßig freitags von 8 bis 9 Uhr. Die Teilnehmenden lasen vorab die Materialien und nutzten die gemeinsame Zeit für Praxisaustausch.

Michael Kallus, als IT Journalist ohne direkten SAP-Projektbezug, gewann tiefe Einblicke in IT-Transformationen. Besonders beeindruckte ihn die Stakeholder-Analyse als Ausdruck von Wertschätzung – keine alleinige Excel-Liste, sondern ein Werkzeug, um Menschen entsprechend ihrer Interessen einzubinden. Auch die Vorbereitung eines Meetings mit Dashboard demonstrierte ihm den Wert professioneller Moderation.

Interesse an weiteren Peer-Learning Aktivitäten

Die Umfrage unter 30 Personen zeigte: 27 möchten weitere Peer-Learning-Aktivitäten durchführen. Die Themenvielfalt reicht von SAP Activate, Key User Management, WalkMe und Sustainability über KI-Anwendungen bis zu Change Management Vertiefungen in Change Impact Analysis und Leadership im OCM-Kontext. Dabei dominierten die SAP Themen stark, gefolgt von Vertiefung in Change Management Themen. Anbei eine Grafik dazu:

Feedback zum Leitfaden und der Durchführung.

Auf die Frage, ob Interesse an Ask-me-Anything Sessions wöchtentlich bestanden hätte für mehr Guidance war die Rückmeldung geteilt – die Hälfte hätten es hilfreich gefunden, die andere Hälfte nicht.

Verbesserungspotenzial

Folgende Wünsche wurden mehrfach genannt:

  • Mehr Praxisbezug und Best Practices – einige wünschten sich mehr konkrete Unternehmensbeispiele und Details zu Tools
  • Mehr inhaltliche Tiefe – Wunsch nach konkreteren Aufgaben, Mini-Challenges und detaillierteren Inhalten

Ein konstruktiver Vorschlag wurde dann kurz diskutiert: Die direkte Verlinkung von Podcasts und Blogs zu relevanten Kapiteln im Leitfaden. Denn bei uns gibt es einige Fallstudien und Good-Practices, die wir dokumentiert haben. Dies würde den Mehrwert erhöhen, ohne großen zusätzlichen Aufwand zu verursachen.

Feedback vom Orga-Team

Wir als Organisatoren stellten zudem fest, dass wir als nicht-teilnehmende Moderatoren weniger Einblick in die Gruppendynamik hatten als in früheren Formaten, bei denen wir selbst Mitglieder in Lerngruppen waren. Wir hätten uns auch mehr ganz konkretes inhaltliches Feedback zum Leitfaden gewünscht. Das bestehende Feedback wird noch voll eingearbeitet.

Ihr könnt direkt im Leitfaden auf GitHub auf den jeweiligen Seiten unten das Feedback einarbeiten.

Die Organisation war weniger aufwändig als erwartet - die Hauptarbeit und Dynamik fanden in den Gruppen selbst statt, die Steuerung von außen war gering.

Die Teilnehmenden haben wir als überwiegend engagiert wahrgenommen. Die Durchführung mit nur einem Thema und in einer Sprache (Deutsch) war einfach und effizient. Früher hatten wir Lernzirkel einmal zu verschiedenen Themen weltweit – was aufgrund der Sprachen und Zeitzonen viel komplexer und aufwändiger.

Inspirierende Aussagen aus der Session

Durchs Tun kommt man auf immer mehr Ideen, was man noch machen kann." (Simon Dückert zum KI-Einsatz)

"Die Stakeholder-Analyse ist ein wichtiges Drehkreuz, weil man damit die Beteiligten entsprechend einbindet – das ist Wertschätzung den Menschen gegenüber und keine Excel-Liste." (Michael Kallus)

"Die größte Lernerfahrung kommt im Austausch. Der Leitfaden ist wie ein Trainingsplan, aber die Laufgruppe macht den Unterschied." (Synthese der Diskussion)

"SAP einführen ist wichtig, aber am Ende, wenn es der Mensch nicht mitnimmt, dann ist die Transformation nicht gelungen." (Adelheid)

"Jedes Projekt ist etwas anders und hat andere Knackpunkte. Der Austausch und andere Sichtweisen zu hören sind enorm hilfreich.“ (Teilnehmenden-Feedback)

Verfügbare Ressourcen und nächste Schritte

Kommt in unsere SAP Training & Change Community!!

Die Community bietet mehrere Formate: monatliche "Kaffeeecken" mit Impulsvorträgen und Austausch, LinkedIn-Gruppe, SAP Community-Bereich sowie den EducationNewscast-Podcast mit Fallstudien. Hier die Links: 

  • LinkedIn Gruppe mit regelmäßigen Updates  - SAP Community Gruppe zu OCM mit vielen Blogs
  • Monatlich virtuelle Kaffee Ecke rund um Learning, Change, Adoption

Hört in unseren Podcast auf Spotify  oder Apple Podcasts rein – hier gibt es auch immer Change als Thema. Ein weiteres Angebot ist das SAP Change Basecamp – ein Workshop zu wesentlichen Change Management Aufgaben für ein SAP S/4HANA Cloud Projekt entlang SAP Activate - Termine gibt es auf Anfrage mit Durchführung gern bei Euch im Haus. Kommt gerne auf uns zu.

Resümee

Das Learning Circle Format zu Change Management in SAP-Projekten hat gezeigt: Strukturiertes Peer-Learning funktioniert, wenn Selbstorganisation, Flexibilität und engagierte Teilnehmende zusammenkommen. Der Leitfaden bietet Orientierung, die eigentliche Lernerfahrung entsteht durch den Austausch verschiedener Perspektiven und Erfahrungen.

Besonders wertvoll ist die Erkenntnis, dass erfolgreiche Transformation nicht primär eine Frage der Technologie oder Methodik ist, sondern der Menschen. Change Management bedeutet Wertschätzung, Einbindung und transparente Kommunikation – Prinzipien, die sich auch im Lernformat selbst widerspiegeln.

Die hohe Nachfrage nach weiteren Formaten und vertiefenden Themen zeigt den Bedarf an kontinuierlichem Austausch. Das Community-Ökosystem mit Podcast, regelmäßigen Treffen und verschiedenen Lernformaten bietet dafür eine gute Basis. Die Integration von KI-Tools in Change-Prozesse eröffnet neue Möglichkeiten, erfordert aber weiterhin den menschlichen Austausch als Kern erfolgreicher Transformation. Wir bleiben dran und freuen uns auf die nächsten Community Sessions.

entry.title: Re: Tax Card data for Qatar region
entry.content:
Why the System behaves this way is because, the system distinguishes between:

  • Resident suppliers → Tax card required, but no withholding tax.
  • Non‑resident suppliers → Tax card required and withholding tax details must be entered.

That is why when you flag the BP as Non‑resident, the system enforces withholding tax setup.

So the key take away is

  • Suppliers outside Qatar must be maintained as Non‑resident → this is correct.
  • The system requires WHT details for non‑residents — this is by design.
  • There is no option to remove the validation in Public Cloud.
  • The only resolution is to maintain WHT codes (even dummy ones if legally acceptable) or classify as Resident as a workaround, but that has compliance implications.

My suggestion is to align with your tax/legal team and then either (a) configure WHT properly for non‑resident suppliers, or (b) raise an SAP incident if you believe the validation is too restrictive for your scenario.

entry.title: Re: Sales Price Rounding Issue S4 HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, the condition technique calculates sequentially:

  • Base condition (ZPR0)
  • Margin condition (ZPRM)
  • Gross condition value (sum of above)

When you override the displayed gross amount, the system still uses the underlying condition base values for subsequent conditions. Taxes and net value are calculated on the condition record values, not on the overridden amount, unless you explicitly adjust the condition base value.

Some workarounds are

Instead of only overriding the condition amount, also adjust the condition base value using the extension point PRCG_DOC_ITEM_CONDITION_BASE (if available in your release). This ensures subsequent conditions (like tax) reference the corrected rounded value.

Define a new condition type (e.g., ZNET) that calculates the net unit price as Gross Price per Unit = Base Price + (Base Price × Margin). Use this condition type as the pricing base for taxes and net value. This way, rounding is applied at the unit level, not after multiplication.

In Public Cloud, you can use predefined extension points for condition formulas. Write a routine that calculates the unit gross price first, rounds it, and then multiplies by quantity. Assign this routine to your margin condition (ZPRM) or gross condition. This ensures all downstream conditions reference the rounded gross price.

entry.title: Setting Up a Branded SAP Service and Asset Manager Client
entry.content:
Using the SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK), you can build and run a custom client that connects to your SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) mobile application. Once configured, the client can also be packaged and distributed through the Apple App Store, iOS Enterprise App Store, or Google Play Store.

To develop customizations and effectively debug the SSAM client, a proper local development environment is required.

Prerequisites

 Before you begin, ensure the following tools are installed on your machine:

  • Visual Studio Code

  • SAP MDK extension for Visual Studio Code

  • Development tools, including:

    • Node.js

    • NativeScript

    • Xcode (for iOS development)

    • Android Studio (for Android development)

    • React Native (for Windows development)

  • MDK Dependencies Installer.app
    (Included in MDKClient_SDK from SAP Software Center, used to verify required tool versions)

 

SSAM Main Component Naming

Below are the standard naming conventions and versioning used for the main SSAM components:

  • Branding SDK
    SAM.mdkproject folder — version 2511.x.x

  • Plug-in SDK
    extensions folder — version 2511.x.x

  • Metadata
    metadata folder — version 2511.x.x

  • MDK SDK (MDK Client)
    sdk folder (MDK) — version 25.6.x

The SAM–MDK compatibility matrix can be found here:
https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/2933065

 

SSAM Branded Client Structure

When building an SSAM project, there are two possible folder structures:

  1. Standard folder structure

  2. Customized metadata folder structure

These structures determine how metadata and branding assets are organized and consumed by the MDK client.

IMPORTANT: Develop any customization on the app as a separate component in a Mobile Development Kit project. Developing customizations as a component makes it easier to maintain customizations during upgrades, as it isolates custom code. Isolating your custom code eliminates the chance of overwriting when you implement a new release.

Standard Folder Structure

Customized Metadata Folder Structure

 

Building the Project

Once the project is set up correctly, verify that both the .cim file and the Application.app file are properly maintained.

The .cim file and Application.app define key information such as the application name and root path. One of the most important aspects of building a client is ensuring that the project name and folder structure are correct. If these are incorrect, the build process may fail.

Below are sample folder and project naming conventions shown in the screenshots:

Once the project structure is verified, you can begin the build process.

  1. Open a terminal and navigate to the project root folder.

  2. Run the following command:

     
    sdk/install.command

  3. After the installation completes, the create client commands will be available in the sdk folder.

  4. Navigate to the sdk directory:

     
    cd sdk

  5. Run the create client command:

     
    ./create-client.command -m /Your_root/ZSAPAssetManager/SAM.mdkproject/

If the process completes successfully, you should see the message “Application is ready” in the terminal.

 

Running the Application

Once the build completes successfully, a new folder named sdk/SvcAssetMgr is created in your SAM project root directory.

To run the application, open a terminal and execute:

cd sdk/SvcAssetMgr

Run on iOS

tns run ios --justlaunch

Note:
If no physical device is connected and no simulator is running, an iOS simulator will start automatically.

Run on Android

tns run android --justlaunch

Note:
If no physical device is connected and no emulator is running, an Android emulator will start automatically.

The --justlaunch option is optional, but it can significantly speed up application deployment.

With --justlaunch:

  • The application is launched once, and the command exits immediately.

Without --justlaunch:

  • The tns process continues running in the background.

  • Application logs are streamed to the terminal.

  • File watching may be enabled, allowing automatic redeployment when files change (behavior may vary).

 

Debugging the Custom Client

You can debug the custom client directly from Visual Studio Code.

  1. Open the Run and Debug pane on the left side of VS Code.

  2. Create a new launch.json file.

  3. When prompted, choose the MDK configuration.

VS Code will generate a default launch.json file. You must then add the appRoot property to the configuration.

The approot should point to the application folder inside your sdk folder. You can have different app names so make sure you use the right one in the launch.json

Once this is configured, you can attach the debugger to both Android and iOS devices and debug the metadata directly from VS Code.

 

Further Documentation

We provide a general Building and Branding SSAM documentation that describes the Mobile Services deployment process in detail.

Additionally, the SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) offers documentation on creating custom clients.

These resources will help you further customize SSAM, including guidance on branding your customized application.

entry.title: Problem using InventoryGenExits with products across different bin locations
entry.content:
I am working with InventoryGenExits and it usually works fine. However, I now have an issue with an item that has two bin locations. For example:

  • BinAbsEntry 1 → Warehouse "001", BinCode "001-UBICACIÓN-DE-SISTEMA" (36 units)

  • BinAbsEntry 3 → Warehouse "001", BinCode "001-MANTENIMIENTO" (5 units)

By default, I always need to withdraw products from BinCode "001-UBICACIÓN-DE-SISTEMA". I tried sending the following JSON structure:  

array:4 [  "DocDate" => "20251217"
  "DocDueDate" => "20251217"
  "Comments" => "Entregas insumos pañol 17-12-2025, FORTINWEB, realizado por JUAN MORENO"
  "DocumentLines" => array:1 [
    0 => array:9 [
      "ItemCode" => "SHEP0018"
      "Quantity" => 1.0
      "WarehouseCode" => "001"
      "CostingCode" => "EF0004"
      "U_PG_Retira" => 577
      "UseBaseUnits" => "tYES"
      "UoMEntry" => -1
      "InventoryQuantity" => 1.0
      "BinAllocations" => array:1 [
        0 => array:4 [
          "BinAbsEntry" => 1
          "Quantity" => 1.0
          "BinActionType" => "batFromWarehouse"
          "BaseLineNumber" => 0
        ]
      ]
    ]
  ]]

 

But I get the following error: 1470000341 - The item "SHEP0018" is not fully allocated to the location "001".

How can I force the system to take the quantity only from the specific bin location I define (BinAbsEntry 1) .  Can someone please help me?

entry.title: Re: Usage based billing_ Apportionment of revenue to the...
entry.content:
Hello @sai_sandeep 

Thank you for your question

Your understanding of cost postings is correct. This is not a configuration error but a standard public cloud design. You cannot automatically configure public cloud to post multiple revenue lines per employee for a single usage-based billing item. Which would lead to a contradiction of the standard revenue recognition design.

Given the public cloud limitation, for you to achieve your Revenue by employee as a KPI, I recommend:

Is for you to use analytics and not FI posting to calculate revenue per employee.:

  • In your time entry, make sure you can identify which employee worked on which order or project. This seems to be the case already today since you see cost by employee.
  • Ensure you add employee as a characteristic in Margin Analysis, or you make use of a Custom Analytical Query.
    • The Custom Analytical Query helps you read revenue and WIP at contract/Order/Project level and
    • relates it back to employees through the recorded time.
  • You may also consider creating an SAC Fiori KPI for your Revenue by employee.
    • This will require you to build a query that calculates employee share of revenue based on the employees’ hours or cost proportions
    • Which you can then expose as a KPI in your Analytics Story or Fiori tiles.

This approach basically ensures you avoid fine-grained profit centers for every person.

In summary, the best practice is for you to:

  • Keep profit centers at organisation or project level and,
  • Use analytics with employee as characteristic to calculate.

If you absolutely need revenue on employee profit centers, you can on approximate this through the periodic CO allocation from project profit center to employee profit centers. I do not recommend this because of its complexity.

This Blog provides some good insights: Project Billing for Customer Projects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Check out this similar question: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/usage-based-billing/qaq-p/12341024

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Calculated column in Story report
entry.content:
I believe the problem is that each goal is being returned as their own row. Calculated fields don't work across multiple rows.  In order to Sum the weight for each goal, the goal would need to be on the same row.  The solution is to:

  1. Copy the Primary Goal Object twice so you now have 3 Primary Goal Objects in your data model - one for each goal category
  2. Set a Simple filter on each object to isolate each goal category to only one value e.g. Goal 1 or Goal 2 or Goal 3
  3. Rename the weight field for each object to clearly identify the weight it represents - it should be the same as the filter you applied e.g Goal 1 Weight or Goal 2 Weight etc.
  4. Now that you have a column for each weight category and values all on the same row you can create a calculated column called Total Weight that simply does the math of Goal 1 Weight = Goal 2 Weight + Goal 3 Weight

entry.title: Re: Considerations when implementing IAS for SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
Hi @Ethan_Dai - The way I have been able to retrigger the IAS Welcome email is by following these steps: 

First, verify the email is correct for the onboardee. 

In Onboarding Dashboard, go to the onboardee's record, and click on Actions > Restart Onboarding

Do not start the process again, however -- not yet. Do not click on Start to resubmit.

Wait until after the next IAS sync happens (mine is set to every 30 minutes, but unfortunately it's a rolling 30 minutes so I need to log into the Admin Console to check on this timing).

Verify the user has been removed in IAS.

Then go back into Onboarding and start the process by clicking on Start and re-submit the onboardee.

Check again in IAS Console after the next sync runs to verify the onboardee is again in IAS. If you check the troubleshooting logs, you'll find that the Welcome email has been sent again.

This works. I hope this helps you!

~Julie

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: AI Insights, SAP Community Memories, and What’s Coming in 2026!
entry.content:
Today marks the final edition of Community Voice for 2025, and we are happy to bring you great featured blog posts, valuable insights from one of our SAP Mentors, and wonderful memories from SAP TechEd. Looking back, we are incredibly proud of our SAP community members for their contributions, energy, and commitment to helping others, sharing experiences, and making the SAP ecosystem an inspiring place to be part of. 

This edition is also a moment to express our gratitude to you, our readers, who continuously engage with our content. Without your support and participation, none of this would be possible. Thank you for being here and for showing up to so many other community members. 

While this newsletter takes a short break during the holiday season, we want to let you know that we will be back at the beginning of January 2026. For now, let’s look at what has been happening in the SAP Community over the past few weeks and what exciting events are planned for the year ahead! 

Let’s dive in! 

Featured Blog Posts

Reflections about how far AI will go  

The more we talk about AI, the more people tend to pick sides. Whether you like it or not, the implementation of Artificial Intelligence is accelerating everywhere, and this year SAP demonstrated how well it is prepared to bring powerful AI solutions to its customers. SAP Community member and former SAP employee Pierre Col, who recently retired, opened an important discussion about this topic. In his blog post, he highlights how strongly SAP is positioned in the market and showcases the power of its AI offerings. At the same time, he raises concerns about the impact that AI, and humanoid robots in particular, may have on human employment. Overall, this is a valuable blog post that encourages thoughtful reflection on what the near future may look like and invites the community to share ideas, perspectives, and engage in meaningful discussion in the comments. 

Read Pierre full blog post here 

Guide to Accessibility in SAP Fiori/UI5 for beginners  

If you are looking to understand what accessibility really is in UI development, common pitfalls in UI5 apps and how to start building accessible features without feeling overwhelmed, this blog post is for you. SAP´s Guruprasad, shares a personal journey of discovering why accessibility is not extra work, but a fundamental part of building usable applications, particularly when working with SAP Fiori and UI5. Through practical examples, he introduces useful tools and techniques for testing accessibility, including keyboard-only navigation, screen readers, contrast checkers, and browser inspection tools. This is a beginner-friendly and practical guide for everyone who wants to build inclusive, high-quality SAP UI applications.  

Read Guruprasad full blog post here 

SAP Mentor Leonardo Araujo insights on AI journey at SAP TechEd 2025  

One of the most valuable aspects of SAP TechEd 2025 was the insightful sessions delivered by experienced developers and industry experts. We had the pleasure of hearing from many SAP Mentors and Champions who brought important conversations to the spotlight, and one of the standout sessions was presented by SAP Mentor Leonardo Araujo. His session was based on his earlier blog post”The AI Stack Is Ready — Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology“. Leonardo explained that the AI technology stack, especially for generative and agent-based AI, is already largely in place. Capabilities such as secure AI, RAG scenarios, agent building, orchestration, and flexible LLM choices are now well supported by SAP BTP and reinforced by recent SAP innovations announced at SAP TechEd. He also emphasized key realities of generative AI, including its probabilistic nature, the critical importance of clearly defined problem statements, and the risks of applying AI to broken or poorly designed processes. Therefore, Leonardo shared practical recommendations around experimentation, fail-fast approaches, and the journey from pilot to production. His content is a must-read, offering valuable insights into why some AI pilots fail and how organizations can achieve success. 

Read Leonardo Araujo full blog post here 

SAP Cloud ALM: Codeless Automation for RISE Transitions 

Nowadays, regression testing often becomes a challenge because of the necessity teams need to balance thorough test coverage with the pressure to release quickly. SAP´s Paulo Boschetti explores how Tricentis Test Automation for SAP integrated with SAP Cloud ALM can help teams address this challenge in a more practical way. Paulo explains that tools only succeed when supported by strong testing practices, clear strategies, and skilled teams. While Tricentis TTA offers a powerful, codeless, and SaaS-based approach, its real value comes from enabling functional teams to actively participate in automation rather than replacing testing expertise. Considering real-world implementations in Latin America, particularly during RISE with SAP transitions and S/4HANA upgrades, he shows how this solution significantly reduces regression testing effort and accelerates delivery cycles. He also makes sure to remind readers to invest equally in your team by training them and supporting skills development.  

Read Paulo Boschetti full blog post here 

Community News 

SAP TechEd 2025: Moshe Naveh Recap  

SAP TechEd 2025 was definitely a highlight of the year for the SAP Community, and Community Advocate Moshe Naveh shared an engaging recap of his experience, highlighting some of the great moments he spent with community members in Berlin and Bengaluru. In his blog post, he reflects on how refreshing it was to return to on-site events, especially since his last SAP TechEd attendance was seven years ago. Moshe also encourages community members to keep the momentum going through online gatherings and continued engagement. For those feeling inspired to share their own stories, he previously published a helpful guide on using an AI-based simplified blogging methodology, making it easier for anyone to start contributing and sharing their experiences with the community. 

SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025 

At the end of November, one of the most anticipated events for the SAP Community Gurugram location group took place: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025. The event offered a full day of learning and idea exchange among community members and SAP developers, consultants, architects and many more. Hosted at SAP Labs India in Gurugram, the event opened with a keynote by Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM. Alongside the keynote, the agenda covered a wide range of SAP topics presented by multiple speakers and lots of network breaks. The day concluded with a closing ceremony followed by snacks and informal talks, giving attendees the opportunity to connect. If you would like to explore more highlights (or check if you appear in any of the photos) be sure to read SAP´s Neeraj Manocha latest blog post here for a full recap of the SIT Gurugram! 

2026 Upcoming Events

As 2025 comes to an end, we are already looking ahead to 2026 with many exciting plans! SAP community location groups have already added dates for upcoming gatherings to their agendas, giving you the perfect opportunity to mark your calendar early and plan ahead. These events are a great chance to connect, learn, and meet fellow SAP community members in your area.  

Check out the list below to see the events already scheduled for 2026: 

  • 20 of January: SAP CodeJam - Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Bielefeld, Germany) 
  • 21 of January: SAP CodeJam - Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core ( Hyderabad, India ) 
  • 22 of January: SAP CodeJam ABAP: SAP BTP, ABAP Environment & RAP ( Hyderabad, India ) 
  • 23 of January: SAP Stammtisch Wroclaw - January Edition! (Registration is closed) 
  • 29 of January: SAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India) 
  • 09 of February: Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Pune, India) 
  • 26 of February:  Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Gent, Belgium) 
  • 14 of March: SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026 – Brasil 
  • 17 of March: SAP TALK WOMEN CWB 2026- Curitiba, Brasil 
  • 26 of September: SAP Inside Track Porto 2026 - Portugal 
  • 31 of October: SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026- Brasil  

Happy Holidays!  

We would like to express our sincere gratitude to the entire SAP community for the passion, collaboration, and knowledge you share every day. Your contributions and willingness to support one another are what makes this community so special. 2025 was a wonderful year, filled with meaningful lessons and lasting memories, whether online or on-site. Every SAP Inside Track, Stammtisch, meet-up, and even informal conversation made a significant impact, strengthening our connections and contributing to the growth of our community. We wish you a joyful holiday season with peace, happiness, and time with loved ones. We look forward to continuing this journey together in 2026. Happy holidays from all of us in the SAP Community!

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud Transportation Management
entry.content:
Good day @partha2day 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, TM in public cloud is designed to plan and execute transports that are part of your own logistics network and not pure vendor-to-customer drop shipments. That means, the inbound delivery you used in your workaround is not treated as TM-relevant for freight-unit building in this process, therefore leading to the system not creating any freight document. So, this is not an error but a pure system design.

The public cloud does not provide any switch or SSCUI that helps you add 3rd-party inbound deliveries to the freight-unit building framework.

Best practice is for you to:

  1. Use manually created standalone freight orders in TM or through custom integration and link them through references to your 3rd-party PO/sales order, or
  2. Keep the pure 3rd-party drop shipments outside TM, whilst you handle freight through purchasing or external tools.

 

The following reference (IZQ) provides some insights: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/61e246f4b34c4e1790d8b7651c0b40a8/44ed805358c34025ba6d11d7e2f43cfc.html?locale=en-US

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: From Legacy to Modern Auth: Enabling OpenID Connect in SAP BusinessObjects Step-by-step
entry.content:
• Introduction : OpenID Connect (OIDC)
  • BI Platform : OIDC Authentication in nutshell
  • BI Platform : OIDC Authentication vs SAML Authentication
  • Authorization Server :configuration steps
  • BI Platform : Central Management Console Configuration
  • BI Platform : BI Launchpad configuration

Introduction : OpenID Connect (OIDC)

Let’s kick things off by quickly understanding what OpenID Connect (OIDC) is:


OpenID Connect (OIDC) is a simple and secure way for apps and websites to confirm who you are—without making you create yet another password. It’s built on top of OAuth 2.0, a widely used standard for secure access. Instead of storing passwords, OIDC lets your app rely on a trusted service (called an Authorization Server) to handle login. When you sign in, the app gets a verified “identity token” and some basic profile details, so it knows who you are.

Why is this great?

  • Safer: No password storage means fewer chances of data breaches.
  • Convenient: Works across web, mobile, and JavaScript apps.
  • Flexible: Supports extra features like encrypted data and single sign-out.

In short, OIDC answers the question: “Who is using this app right now?”—in a secure, modern way.

So, what is Authorization Server and how it is related to Identity check and Authentication.....

Identity Provider (IdP): This is the service that authenticates the user and provides identity information (claims), in simple terms, Who authenticates the user and provides identity data.. Examples: Azure AD, Okta, Google Identity, SAP Cloud Identity Services.

Authorization Server: This is the component that issues tokens (ID token, access token) as part of the OAuth 2.0/OIDC flow, in simple terms, Who issues tokens and enforces OAuth/OIDC protocol. It handles the authorization and token exchange.

In most implementations, the Identity Provider and Authorization Server are part of the same system. For example: Azure AD acts as both IdP and Authorization Server. Okta does the same.

So, while they play conceptually different roles, in practice, you’ll often configure just one endpoint because the IdP usually includes the Authorization Server functionality.

Following is the simple block diagram explaining the OIDC flow: 

Now that we know what OIDC is and why it matters, let’s move on to see how you can configure it in SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform. Starting with BI 4.3 SP02, SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform introduced native support for OpenID Connect (OIDC) authentication. This means BI Launchpad can now leverage modern, secure, and password-free login flows using trusted identity providers like SAP Cloud Identity Services, Azure AD or Google...

Note:

  • This information in the below sections are applicable for BI 4.3 SP02 and above and BI 2025 versions.
  • For this explanation I have used Azure AD (Microsoft Entra ID) as an Authorization Server / Identity Provider. Otherwise, you can use, any of the Authorization Server / Identity Provider which supports OAuth 2.0 protocol & OIDC.

                                                                                                                                                               Back to top ⮭

 

 

BI Platform : OIDC Authentication in nutshell

As mentioned in my what's new blog for BI 4.3 SP02 release, OIDC authentication is introduced along with the OAuth SSO functionality. Let us see, what we need to know about OIDC authentication implementation in BI Platform:

  1. OpenID Connect Authentication is implemented in BI Platform on top of Enterprise Authentication. 
  2. Works with all the Authorization Server / IDP which support OpenID Connect Authentication based on OAuth 2.0 protocol.
  3. Uses the Authorization Server configuration in Central Management Console, this means it uses the configuration stored in the BI Platform backend. 
  4. User base at your IDP, with which you are planning to use OIDC in BI Platform should have corresponding user accounts in BI Platform as an Enterprise aliases with the same Email (as BI Platform implementation for OIDC is based on email claim only.) which is configured for those users at IDP. Hence, these user accounts in BI platform need to be created in advance. (Please refer point 24 in the Central Management Console configuration section below). 
  5. OpenID Connect Authentication in BI Platform is only supported for BI Launchpad and OpenDocument client applications.
  6. It is mandatory to enable HTTPS for the web applications (BOE & biprws) to configure OAuth SSO and / or OpenID Connect Authentication in BI Platform, as most Authorization Servers or IDPs insist to configure Redirect URI with https (Please refer Point no. 7 in Authorization Server configuration steps section below). Moreover using https is secure way and recommended method for communication over the wire.

 

                                                                                                                                                                 Back to top ⮭

 

 

BI Platform : OIDC Authentication vs SAML Authentication

As you already aware that BI Platform also supports SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) based Authentication for web applications like BI Launchpad and CMC, wondering which method is recommended?

As you know, SAML Authentication support in BI Platform exists much earlier, that is from BI 4.2 SP05 release onwards. And it was the de facto choice for many organizations deploying SAP BusinessObjects. As it was better choice that time when compared existing authentication methods, when compared to the basic authentication (password based) in security perspective and to platform native SSO methods (like Windows AD, LDAP or SAP) in complexity and modern protocol perspective.

But now that BI Platform also got OpenID Connect Authentication support, so let us see which is better and recommended choice....

FeatureSAML (Security Assertion Markup Language)OpenID Connect (OIDC)
Primary goal
(Core Function)		Authentication & Authorization (XML-based assertions) 
using IdP→SP trust and SAML assertions.
Authentication (identity verification)
standard way to get identity claims
& Authorization (via OAuth)
Message & token format
(Data Format)		XML (Heavyweight, complex)JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) (Lightweight, simple)
Protocol StandardsXML StandardsOAuth 2.0 (extension of it)
User ExperienceCan be more complex/heavyweight.Simpler, smoother with user-agent redirection (e.g., "Sign in with SSO").
IntegrationCan be complex to implementEasier integration
Transport styleVarious bindings (HTTP Redirect, POST, SOAP)Simple HTTPS flows (HTTP Redirect, POST).
Actors / terminology
Identity Provider (IdP) and Service Provider (SP) exchanging AuthnRequest/Response and assertions
OpenID Provider (OP) and Relying Party (RP/client); uses OAuth-style endpoints.
How the “login result” is delivered
Typically via browser POST/Redirect bindings carrying SAML Response back to SP’s ACS endpoint
Typically via redirects to RP with tokens/code (Authorization Code / Implicit / Hybrid flows are defined)
Identity attributes / claims
Attributes carried as XML attributes inside the assertion; relies on SP/IdP agreement (often via metadata + mapping)
 Uses claims carried in JWT and/or returned by UserInfo (scopes map to claim sets).
Metadata / discovery
 
Typically depends on SAML metadata exchange (XML metadata with endpoints/certs) before federation works
 
OIDC ecosystems commonly use standardized discovery patterns (OIDC defines a broader spec family including discovery/registration)
 
 
Typical pain points
XML + signing/encryption + metadata can be verbose and configuration-heavy compared to OIDC
 
 
Must choose correct flow and validate tokens properly; still requires careful security configuration
BIP: End-to-End DB SSO (for reporting DBs)
No
Yes
BIP: Works without Trusted Authentication enabled in BI Platform
No
Yes
BIP: Native implementation (without using third party software)
No (And moreover SAML implementation in BI Platform is at the level of Application Server and BI Platform backend does not know about it, as mentioned in the above point, BIP treats it as a Trusted Authentication)
Yes
BIP: Roadmap
No plans to improve or innovate only maintenance
Innovations / Improvements are lined up

As you can see with the above comparison, it is evident that OIDC is the better choice when compared to SAML in BI Platform, and also OIDC is recommended as it is the latest and based on modern protocol.

Hope you got the fair Idea about What is OIDC, and how it is implemented in BI Platform, why you can choose to go for it against legacy and SAML Authentication. So, let us move on to configuration part.

 

Here’s how you can set it up step by step......                                                                              Back to top ⮭

 

 

Authorization Server : configuration steps

To enable OpenID Connect (OIDC) authentication for any client application, the first step is to register that application (known as the Relying Party—in this case, the BI Platform) with the Authorization Server. This registration ensures that when the client initiates an OpenID Connect request, the OpenID Provider (OP) or Authorization Server can identify and trust the client application. By establishing this trust relationship, the Authorization Server can securely issue tokens and provide user identity information to the registered client.

Sign in to your Authorization Server admin Portal

  1. Here in our example Authorization Server is Microsoft Entra ID, hence, go to https://portal.azure.com.
  2. Navigate to Microsoft Entra ID (previously Azure Active Directory).
  3. In Microsoft Entra ID, select App registrations under Manage section
  4. Click New registration
  5. Enter Name: A descriptive name for your app. for ex: BIPOpenIDAuth
  6. select Supported account types, according to your organizational needs
  7. Enter Redirect URI, by selecting the Web as the platform, the following url - https://<biphostname>:<port>/biprws/v1/oauth2/callback
    • Note: 
      • Replace "biphostname" and "port" with your BOBJ web application deployment details.
      • It is mandatory and also the secure way to use https url.
  8. Click Register
  9. After registration, note down Application (Client) ID, Directory (tenant) ID, from the Overview section of the registered application.
  10. Go to Certificates & Secrets and click on New client secret
  11. Add description and select expiry.
  12. Copy the secret value (you will need this along with Client ID for configuration in CMC)
    • Note: The secret value is displayed only once immediately after creation. Make sure to copy and store it securely at that time. Once you leave this page, the secret will no longer be visible and cannot be retrieved later.
  13. Under API permissions, ensure openid, profile, email, and User.Read permissions are added from Microsoft Graph API as Delegated permissions by clicking on Add a permission
  14. (Optional) Add Files.ReadWrite.All and offiline_access permissions, if in case, if you want to use the same configuration for making Microsoft OneDrive as Scheduling destination as well as use Office documents as data source for Web Intelligence documents.
  15. Add any additional permissions your app needs.
  16. Grant admin consent if required.

Collect the following details, before proceeding for the next step

  • Directory (tenant) ID
  • Issuer URL - https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenant}/v2.0
  • Application (Client) ID
  • Client Secret (secret value)
  • Redirect URL

                                                                                                                                                             Back to top ⮭

 

 

BI Platform : Central Management Console Configuration

After completing the configuration on the Authorization Server and obtaining the necessary application details, you can proceed to the Central Management Console (CMC) to configure the BI Platform side. As mentioned in the introduction, SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform introduced native support for OpenID Connect (OIDC) starting with BI 4.3 SP02, along with the underlying OAuth SSO feature. I’ve explained OAuth SSO in detail in another blog, where you’ll also learn about a new application called Authorization Server Configuration under the Applications section in CMC. This application serves as the foundation for all OAuth SSO-based functionalities in the BI Platform, including OAuth SSO for databases and OData, OIDC-based authentication, and scheduling to cloud storage services such as Google Drive and Microsoft OneDrive.

  1. launch http://<biphostname>:<port>/BOE/CMC/ and login with Administrator or delegated admin account having privileges to manage Applications
  2. Navigate to Applications under Manage section
  3. Right click on Authorization Server Configuration and select the Authorization Server Configurations option.
  4. In Authorization Server Configurations pop up, select New Authorization Server Configuration option from Manage drop down menu.
  5. Enter the desired configuration name in the Reference Name text box.
  6. (Optional) Enter the relevant description text in the Description text box.
  7. If you are using BI 2025 and above, then you will see the option to choose the Grant Type, in that keep the default option Authorization Code.
    • Note:
      • In earlier versions of BI Platform (Prior to BI 2025), this option was not available, and Authorization Code Grant Type was implicit value in those BI Platform versions.
      • Authorization Code flow is most secure and recommended Grant Type for the OIDC Authentication scenario. BI Platform only allows OIDC authentication via the Authorization Code flow grant type only.
      • BI Platform was only supporting Authorization Code flow priori to BI 2025, but from BI 2025 onwards, it supports Authorization Code flow & Client Credentials flow.
        • Authorization Code flow for OIDC & OAuth SSO scenarios.
        • Client Credential flow for OAuth SSO scenarios. (which is meant for server-to-server or machine-to-machine authorization)
        • For more information on Grant Types refer OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework.
  8. Select the checkbox labeled Enabled for "OpenID Connect" Authentication, to indicate the configuration is ready for using the OpenID Connect (OIDC) Authentication.
    • Observe that, Issuer URI, JSON Web Key Sets URI (jwks_uri) and ID Token Signing Algorithm fields gets enabled.
  9. Enter the Issuer URI in the corresponding text box. for Microsoft Entra ID, it is https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenant}/v2.0 (replace tenant value with your tenant identifier)
  10. (Optional) Click on Get details button next to Issuer URI text box after entering the correct value.
    • CMC UI has functionality implemented to fetch and fill the values automatically for JSON Web Key Sets URI (jwks_uri), Authorization Endpoint, Token Endpoint.
    • If you do not want use this Get details functionality then you need to fill jwks_uri, authorization endpoint and token endpoint manually.
  11. Enter the JSON Web Key Sets URI (jwks_uri) (if not fetched through Get details), in the corresponding text box. for Microsoft Entra ID, it is https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenant}/discovery/v2.0/keys (replace tenant value with your tenant identifier)
  12. For ID Token Signing Algorithm, BI Platform supports only RS256, hence it is the only value available in the list and selected by default.
  13. Enter the Authorization Endpoint (if not fetched through Get details), in the corresponding text box. for Microsoft Entra ID, it is https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenant}/oauth2/v2.0/authorize  (replace tenant value with your tenant identifier)
  14. Enter the Token Endpoint (if not fetched through Get details), in the corresponding text box. for Microsoft Entra ID, it is https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenant}/oauth2/v2.0/token (replace tenant value with your tenant identifier)
    • Note:
      • If in case, your Authorization server, which you are planning to use for configuring OIDC Authentication in BI Platform is capable of and enabled with "OAuth 2.0 Mutual TLS Client Authentication and Certificate-Bound Access Tokens" then in the Token Endpoint text box may get filled with the alternative token endpoint than the conventional end point.
        • Because when Mutual TLS Client Authentication and Certificate-Bound Access Tokens functionality enabled at the Authorization server side, then the OpenID Connect discovery will contain the "mtls_endpoint_aliases" JSON object  consists of one or more endpoint parameters, such as token_endpoint, revocation_endpoint, introspection_endpoint, etc. For more information on mtls_endpoint_aliases refer RFC 8705.
        • Here is the example for Microsoft Entra Id with common discovery url, where in which you can observe the "mtls_endpoint_aliases" with an alternative token_endpoint along with conventional token_endpoint url... which will be in the following format: https://mtlsauth.microsoft.com/{tenantid}/oauth2/v2.0/token 
          {
  "token_endpoint": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/oauth2/v2.0/token",
  "token_endpoint_auth_methods_supported": [
    "client_secret_post",
    "private_key_jwt",
    "client_secret_basic",
    "self_signed_tls_client_auth"
  ],
  "jwks_uri": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/discovery/v2.0/keys",
  "response_modes_supported": [
    "query",
    "fragment",
    "form_post"
  ],
  "subject_types_supported": [
    "pairwise"
  ],
  "id_token_signing_alg_values_supported": [
    "RS256"
  ],
  "response_types_supported": [
    "code",
    "id_token",
    "code id_token",
    "id_token token"
  ],
  "scopes_supported": [
    "openid",
    "profile",
    "email",
    "offline_access"
  ],
  "issuer": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenantid}/v2.0",
  "request_uri_parameter_supported": false,
  "userinfo_endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/oidc/userinfo",
  "authorization_endpoint": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/oauth2/v2.0/authorize",
  "device_authorization_endpoint": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/oauth2/v2.0/devicecode",
  "http_logout_supported": true,
  "frontchannel_logout_supported": true,
  "end_session_endpoint": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/oauth2/v2.0/logout",
  "claims_supported": [
    "sub",
    "iss",
    "cloud_instance_name",
    "cloud_instance_host_name",
    "cloud_graph_host_name",
    "msgraph_host",
    "aud",
    "exp",
    "iat",
    "auth_time",
    "acr",
    "nonce",
    "preferred_username",
    "name",
    "tid",
    "ver",
    "at_hash",
    "c_hash",
    "email"
  ],
  "kerberos_endpoint": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/kerberos",
  "mtls_endpoint_aliases": {
    "token_endpoint": "https://mtlsauth.microsoft.com/common/oauth2/v2.0/token"
  },
  "tls_client_certificate_bound_access_tokens": true,
  "tenant_region_scope": null,
  "cloud_instance_name": "microsoftonline.com",
  "cloud_graph_host_name": "graph.windows.net",
  "msgraph_host": "graph.microsoft.com",
  "rbac_url": "https://pas.windows.net"
}
      • As mentioned in the above point, Token Endpoint text box gets filled with this alternative token_endpoint value, due to some issue in parsing the discovery information, when you click the "Get details" button in the Authorization Server Configuration page while creating the same in CMC.
      • Hence in such cases you need to manually enter the conventional token_endpoint url, in the Token Endpoint text box. As mentioned above, for Microsoft Entra Id it will be as following: https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenant}/oauth2/v2.0/token (replace tenant value with your tenant identifier)
        • This is because, In BI Platform, the OAuth 2.0 Token implementation for OAuth SSo or for OIDC authentication, it is implemented based on the Client ID and Client Secret only, Certificate based Client Authentication is not yet supported.
  15. Enter the Client ID value in the corresponding text box. (This is the Application (Client) Id which is registered at the Authorization Server for this configuration purpose, refer the above section)
  16. Enter the Client Secret value in the corresponding text box. (This is the Client Secret value you have saved securely after creating it during the Application registration in Authorization Server, refer step 12 in the "Authorization Server Configuration steps" section above, enter that value here.)
  17. Enter the Redirect URL in the corresponding text box. (This should exactly match with the value you have entered for the Redirect URI during the Application registration in Authorization Server, refer step 7 in the "Authorization Server Configuration steps" section above, enter that value here.), which will be in the following format: https://<biphostname>:<port>/biprws/v1/oauth2/callback.
  18. (Optional) Enter the Revocation Endpoint in the corresponding text box. (If your Authorization Server provides one). For Microsoft Entra Id I believe this is as following: https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenantid}/oauth2/v2.0/logout.
  19. Select Type of Resource as Agnostic (which is default value), if you are planning to use this configuration just for OpenID Connect Authentication and/or for any resource access using OAuth SSO. But if you plan to use the same configuration to access Cloud (Drive) storage or OData resource, then select the type accordingly.
    • For example, for the case we are referring here is Microsoft Entra ID then same configuration can be used for "Microsoft Drive", access as well.
  20. Access Type field is specific to Google configuration, this is non-editable field, will be considered automatically with an hardcoded value "Offline" when you select Type of Resource as "GoogleDrive".
  21. (Optional) Custom Parameters field can be used to save any custom parameters required based on your organizational needs according to the configuration done at your Authorization server. Multiple such entries can be entered by clicking on the option +Add more Custom Parameters...
  22. At this moment you can save the configuration by clicking on OK button. Alternatively you can test the configuration entered by clicking on Test Connection button.
    • In case if you plan to test the configuration first and then save, after completing the test, ensure to to re-enter the Client Secret value before clicking on the OK button to save the configuration.
    • When editing the saved configuration, after completing the editing, you need to re-enter the Client Secret value, before clicking on the OK button to save the configuration.
      • Once the form is submitted while creating new or edit the existing, client secret value will not be sent back from the backend (CMS) as this is sensitive data. Hence every time you need re-enter the Client Secret, before saving the configuration, otherwise Client Secret stored previously will be corrupted with the null or junk value in the backend, and all the Authorization and Token workflows will fail.
  23. Once the Authorization Server configuration which is enabled for OpenID Connect Authentication is saved then proceed for the next phase of configuration in the CMC, i.e. selecting this configuration as the configuration to be used for OpenID Connect Authentication.
    1. Navigate to Authentication section under Manage in the Home page.
    2. Click on "Enterprise" from the list of authentication methods.
      • Note:
        1. Please be noted that, OpenID Connect Authentication in BI Platform is implemented on top of "Enterprise" authentication. This means, only user accounts with Enterprise alias will be able to perform the OpenID Connect Authentication into BI Launchpad.
        2. Hence the expectation is all the user accounts in your Identity Provider (IDP) who are expected to perform OpenID login to BI Platform should have corresponding user account in BI Platform with Enterprise alias and same email-id should be available with that user alias, which is there in the user profile for that account at IDP. 
        3. This in turn tells the behavior that, BI Platform will try to find the user account in BI Platform with the matching email-id upon the successful Authorization to allow the user to login to BI Platform. As BI Platform supports only email claim.
    3. In the Enterprise authentication settings page, under "OpenID Connect Authentication" section, select the check-box related to OpenID Connect Authentication to make it enabled.
    4. And then Select the Authorization Server for OpenID Connect Authentication drop down with the configuration name created above in Step 22 of this section.
  24. Once the OpenID Connect Authentication is enabled in the backend, then proceed for the next phase of configuration in the CMC, i.e. to import / create user accounts with Enterprise alias having the same Email-id.
    1. You can achieve this in multiple ways
      1. Manually creating the user by Navigating to Users and Groups section in Home page and click on Manage --> New --> New User option and fill the values for Name, description, password and especially enter the Email with the same email-id which is there for the corresponding user account in IDP.
      2. Importing bulk users - Please refer following SAP Knowledge Base Article 1780406.
      3. Automate creation of user accounts using BI Platform Java SDK or REST SDK. By programmatically querying the user details in IDP and create them as Enterprise users in BI Platform with the same email Id.
  25. With this Configuration at CMC side is completed.

                                                                                                                                                        Back to top ⮭

 

BI Platform : BI Launchpad configuration    

Once the configuration at Central Management Console is completed, proceed to BI Platform side configuration. As mentioned above OIDC based login is implemented only for BI Launchpad and OpenDocument applications in BI Platform.

As specified above OIDC implementation in BI Platform is in backend side configuration, so here in frontend side from the BILP and OD applications we just need to enable openid to indicate the application to initiate the OIDC login flow. For that we need to do the following changes in the corresponding properties of the applications.

  1. Login to the machine where the BI Platform Web applications are deployed.
  2. Stop the application server
  3. Navigate to the folder where the web applications are deployed
  4. In the BOE webapp folder, copy "FioriBI.properties" and "OpenDocument.properties" from WEB-INF/config/default to WEB-INF/config/custom folder.
  5. open these two files from custom folder in any text editor
  6. from both the files keep only the following two properties and remove all the other
    • logon.webssoauthnetication.framework
    • openid.restful.url
  7. Set “logon.webssoauthnetication.framework” value to OpenId in both the files.
  8. Set “openid.restful.url” to restful webservices url of the landscape for example https://<server>:<port>/biprws. in both the files.
  9. Save both the files and start the application server. 
#To Enable Web SSO Authentication workflow. Possible values are (None,OpenId,SAML) 
logon.webssoauthnetication.framework=OpenId

# set the Restful URL which is provided in CMC. example: http://<hostname>:<portNo>/biprws
openid.restful.url=https://<server>:<port>/biprws​
  • Note: 
    • These settings will precedes all the other SSO login configurations supported by BOE web applications. This means for BILP, if you enable this WEBSSO method by setting "logon.webssoauthnetication.framework" then this will precede even if you configure other traditional SSO methods in the .properties file.
    • You can choose to configure the above steps only for BI Launchpad only.
    • You can deploy BOE web applications on different node for enabling the OpenID so that you can target specific groups of users to use this method of login, so that other deployments can serve for the group of users who need to use basic authentication or other methods of SSO login.
    • As you can observe, in the above code snippet, sample for the properties file, either OpenID Connect or SAML any one mechanism only you can enable for your web applications.
    • You can login to the BI Launch Pad via OpenID using ..../BOE/BI/ url, however, once you login using the OpenID Connect authentication to BI Launch Pad you can observe that a dummy context path "WEBSSO" will be added to the url, and this will stay on the url path even after logging out.

Now your landscape is ready to allow the logins based OpenID Connect authentication into BI Launchpad and / or OpenDocument applications. When user access the .../BOE/BI/ url then it will take you to the Authorization Server login page once user authorizes themselves then BI platform will find the matching user with the help of email claim from ID Token, and if user exists with the matching email, then login will be allowed with that user account.

                                                                                                                                                        Back to top ⮭

 

Best Wishes...

-Venkat.

entry.title: Re: MRP Not Converting Demand from Old to New Materials i...
entry.content: The problem here is that the validity interval is controlled by the ECN. So I create an ECN and add materials X, Y, Z. As soon as the ECN goes through and is released, the validity interval for all of the materials, A, B, and C are all tied to that ECN start date and end date is 12/31/2099. For discontinuation groups, the consistnecy is there in image. The BOM and material master are aligned. I did do MD01 as well. The phantom BOM is correctly set on material.

entry.title: Future-ready SAP systems: The role of Clean Core, BTP, and automated change management
entry.content:
As organizations shift to S/4HANA or embrace the Cloud, many are discovering that success is more than just a technology upgrade. It's rethinking how your SAP systems are architected, customized (or extended), and managed. Underlying this is the challenge of innovating quickly while ensuring compliance and system stability.

In this scenario, Clean Core is becoming a foundation for optimizing your SAP environment and future-proofing your SAP systems. Adopting a Clean Core strategy doesn't mean sacrificing business-critical customization or overhauling your ERP systems. You don't have to choose between control and innovation. 

In combination with the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and automated SAP change management, you can modernize your SAP landscape, easily manage change across on-premises and the Cloud, and prepare for the future. 

What is Clean Core, and why does it matter?

Historically, organizations have relied heavily on customizing their SAP system to meet their specific requirements. While this was effective in the short term, these modifications have unintentionally led, over time, to what is commonly known as a dirty core.

 And the cost of a dirty core can be high:

  • Complex and costly upgrades that take longer and are riskier
  • Increased technical debt that slows down innovation
  • Higher total cost of ownership (TCO) due to inefficiencies and ongoing maintenance challenges

Embracing a Clean Core approach addresses these issues. A clean core means keeping your core ERP system as close to standard as possible. It doesn’t mean no more customizations. Custom applications and extensions are built using released APIs and extensibility options – on-stack and side-by-side – which in most cases are external to your core ERP.

Yet, achieving the objectives of Clean Core isn’t just about moving custom code to the appropriate development layer. It’s about following long-established development best practices and using a disciplined approach to design and build a solution.

Without this discipline, adopting a Clean Core methodology doesn’t guarantee a low total cost of ownership or a problem-free future. You can still create brittle and expensive code “outside the core ERP” that can cause performance issues, break during upgrades, or introduce unnecessary complexity.

Other practical challenges to be aware of include:

  • The API you need to support your business may not yet be available to support the business requirement in a Clean Core-compliant way. You can request a new API from SAP, but waiting can delay your Clean Core journey
  • Upskilling teams and partners to work in the new ways needed, and finding the information to navigate the journey needs planning and preparation

These hurdles don’t undermine the value of adopting a Clean Core methodology. A Clean Core and well-implemented code establish a foundation for faster and more predictable SAP upgrades, aligning your business objectives with your ERP investments.

SAP BTP: Innovation without cluttering the core

Organizations still need to innovate, differentiate and extend SAP systems to meet business requirements (without adding technical debt). That’s where SAP BTP comes in.

SAP BTP is a Cloud-based platform that enables you to develop applications, integrate systems, and extend functionality without directly altering your core ERP. This separation is key to maintaining a Clean Core while customizing SAP to your needs. Custom development becomes more loosely coupled with the Core and this reduces interference with SAP upgrades or performance.

How SAP BTP can help achieve and maintain a Clean Core:

  1. Side-by-side extensibility: Build and run custom applications on BTP, keeping your core ERP clean and stable
  2. Integrations: Use SAP Integration Suite to connect SAP and non-SAP systems without modifying the core
  3. Advanced capabilities: Access solutions and services like SAP analytics, AI, and machine learning to enhance decision-making without risking unscheduled downtime of your core SAP system

With SAP BTP you can innovate faster and build scalable applications and extensions that evolve independently of SAP’s upgrade cycle.

However, BTP is not the only way to achieve a Clean Core. SAP provides a multi-tier extensibility model for creating and maintaining customizations independently from the core. For example, you can make minor, non-disruptive extensions directly within your S/4HANA core system without directly modifying SAP standard code.

Why automated change management still matters

Adopting a Clean Core strategy and using SAP BTP to drive your business transformation and future-proof your SAP systems doesn’t eliminate the need to manage change.

It’s not enough to follow best practices when developing SAP changes. You must also apply the same level of discipline to managing, governing, and delivering those changes safely through your SAP landscape.

Whether you are making configuration changes in your core ERP (ECC or S/4HANA) or building applications on the BTP, changes must be managed effectively without interrupting daily business operation. This is where automating change management plays a crucial role. Change must be controlled, traceable, and compliant with regulatory requirements and internal governance.

Automating and enforcing change management ensures:

  • Consistency – every change whether on premises or in the Cloud (BTP) follows a standard, pre-defined process
  • Compliance – internal policies and external regulations are met through configurable automated workflows
  • Visibility – full transparency into every change including what was changed and who approved, ensuring accountability and integrity of the change delivery process

A future-ready SAP system isn’t just about where changes happen (core ERP or Cloud) but also how they’re managed across a hybrid landscape.

The big picture: Digital Transformation and future-ready SAP systems

Clean Core, SAP BTP, and automated change management are not separate strategies, they’re interdependent.

  • Clean Core is the foundation: a simplified, upgrade-ready ERP environment
  • SAP BTP gives you the tools and services to build customizations and extensions without compromising that foundation
  • Automated change management ensures that every change is delivered safely, consistently, and with minimal disruption

Together, a Clean Core strategy, SAP BTP, and automated change management can help you to speed up your digital transformation, move to the Cloud more easily, and future-proof your SAP systems.

entry.title: Statutory Reporting Colombia – Reports show “No data to display” in Run Statutory Reports
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are currently working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and facing issues related to Statutory Reporting for Colombia.

When executing the app Run Statutory Reports and selecting the statutory reports available for Colombia, the system displays alerts indicating that the reports do not have any data to display, even though there are posted transactions in the system.

For our specific case, we need to execute and validate statutory reports that reflect, among others:

  • Withholding taxes (retenciones)

  • Self-withholding taxes (autorretenciones)

  • VAT withholdings

  • Income tax declaration

  • Magnetic media reports (Medios Magnéticos)

During our configuration review, we identified the activity 101071 – Setting Up Your Statutory Reporting, specifically the step where report categories are assigned and mapped to report classifications.

Our questions are:

  1. Could an incorrect or missing mapping in report classification vs. report category within activity 101071 be the root cause of the “no data to display” issue in statutory reports?

  2. What additional configuration points should be reviewed in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to ensure that Colombian statutory and legal reports (taxes, withholdings, magnetic media, income tax, etc.) correctly retrieve and display transactional data?

  3. Are there any mandatory prerequisites (e.g. tax procedure, withholding tax configuration, document types, or localization settings) that must be completed for these reports to work properly?

Any guidance on the relevant configuration activities, apps, or best practices for Colombian statutory reporting would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Re: SAP Screen Personas – Control Personas Button Visibil...
entry.content:
Using the onLoad event will probably not work because the screen actually doesn't get loaded each time you press a button, even though it appears the screen has changed and now you are on a new one. This is due to the EWM RF framework's behavior where the subscreen container changes dynamically upon clicking a button and you are still in the same main screen.

Instead, maybe you can put your check to the onAfterRefresh event, considering that this will run each time a roundtrip to the backend is made. However, to avoid a performance hit, make sure you are coding your check smartly, without causing extra roundtrips. I mean determining the GR posted status once when working with a new delivery and then reusing it by storing its value in the Personas session store.

More than likely though, there are other details to consider in your use case. So, you need to code your logic taking the above-described behavior into account.
